title: After the flood, a rush to preserve drinking water
text:
By ADAM BEAM and SUSANNE M. SCHAFER
Associated Press COLUMBIA, S.C. (AP) - Officials in South Carolina's capital city are rushing to protect one of the area's main sources of drinking water following a massive rainstorm and widespread flooding.
The storm over the weekend caused a canal that serves as the main source of drinking water for about half of the Columbia water system's 375,000 customers has collapsed in two places. Officials are scrambling to build a rock dam to plug the holes and relying on pumps to pull water directly from the canal and the nearby Broad River into the water treatment plant.
Officials stressed the city was not in danger of a water shortage. Still, they urged residents to conserve water and to boil it for at least one minute before using it.
